text: I'm gonna get started so my name is
crystal yen and welcome to leveraging
api's to transform healthcare I'm going
to start off by giving you a quick
introduction to sort of Who I am and
what organization I'm here with so my
background is actually in user
experience I'm a user experience
researcher and designer at a group
called the United States digital service
and specifically I work with an agency
that's part of the Department of Health
and Human Services called the Center for
Medicare and Medicaid so for those of
you who aren't familiar USGS is a
startup we're actually a start-up within
the federal government that was founded
in 2014 as a part of originally to help
fix healthcare.gov since then we've been
embedded in a number of different
federal agencies including DoD DHS SBA
and the VA and our whole mission is to
use design and humans in our design and
modern software development practices to
help deliver better government services
to the American people so here's um I
want to just give you a brief overview
of what I'll talk about today I'll share
a little bit about USGS specifically at
HHS and then I'll talk about two
particular case studies or examples one
is the quality payment program and the
other is the blue button API and then
I'll finally leave you with a couple of
resources in case you're interested in
getting involved in civic technology or
working in something similar with in
your local cities public service or your
state so at USGS specifically within
Health and Human Services we really
believe that the future of healthcare
should be focused on empowering patients
and I don't know if you've ever tried to
do this but if you go today to a
hospital and you go through and you get
a treatment if you asked afterward for a
copy of her medical records your you
might get a very confused look and
actually our administrator when she
asked that I think they you know gave
her a very puzzled look and then came
back
to a couple hours or days later with a
CD so we're trying to make that a little
bit better we believe that if you put
technologists and policy makers in the
same room you can really help advance
that mission of empowering patients a
little bit about the program one of the
programs that we run so since the Center
for Medicare and Medicaid Services runs
two programs Medicare and Medicaid the
two projects I'll talk about today are
more related to Medicare so I'll focus
on giving you just a brief overview of
Medicare it covers fifty five million
patients and there are the amount of
money that goes to Medicare actually
comprises about 3.5 percent of the u.s.
economy so you can imagine if something
breaks there it would be pretty pretty
detrimental not only to the health care
industry but also the economy overall
and as Medicare we're actually the
single largest payer in the United
States which means that we really have
an opportunity when we really push the
envelope forward on technology to set a
standard for expectations when it comes
to private payers and sort of their role
in this healthcare technology
marketplace so the first case study I
want to tell you about is a program for
the quality payment program the what
you're looking at here is a site that we
helped Medicare launch and for those of
you who aren't familiar in the
healthcare industry there's been a big
push to transition from fee-for-service
to value-based care and what that means
is today when you go to a doctor what
most likely happens is if you get a
blood test if you get an x-ray you'll
get a char you'll get a bill at the end
of your visit for each of those services
the problem with this kind of payment
model is it doesn't really incentivize
healthcare systems to have your best
interests
right because they'll make more money if
they give you more stuff when what you
really want is for your interests and
the interests of the healthcare system
to be aligned well they'll they'll get
paid more if you're healthier and so
this whole trend for value-based care
meant that we were really
on a push to help support this and there
was actually a piece of legislation
passed by Congress known as Macra that
had a legislative mandate to have this
transition for Medicare by a certain
date and so for the past two years our
team has been working with a team at CMS
to help support making sure that we roll
out the quality payment program so that
clinicians are able to submit quality
data to CMS and then they're able to get
paid more or less based on the quality
of care that they deliver through our
engagement we have been able to launch
something that helps explain the law to
clinicians in plain language and also
helps them determine if qpp will impact
their Medicare payments the result of
this is that in addition to being able
to learn how the law affects them we
also launched an experience where
clinicians can submit that data through
this website and also submit it through
an API and what we heard in terms of
feedback when we were launched in
January of this year was for someone who
was submitting online they said it was
so easy compared to the previous
experience that they were worried they
didn't actually do it so in the previous
experience they had to go to a website
we'll go to three different websites
actually with three different
authentication models and download an
Excel spreadsheet edit a bunch of data
in that Excel spreadsheet and then
reuploaded and if they did something
wrong they would get feedback on it a
couple months later and they wouldn't
really be able to fix it in time to get
paid in this model they were able to
sort of go to one place instead of three
places and they got that feedback
immediately the other thing that we did
was we launched a way for clinicians and
their groups to submit through an API
and from a developer that we did user
research with they said that this was
you know a quantum leap forward compared
to what CMS had offered before and we
went from having no submissions through
the API to about 15% of the market and
we really hope that this will help set
an expectation for clinicians to demand
that of private payers and that this
data can be shared in more real time to
make it a lot easier for people to do
value-based care and hopefully patients
getting better care the second project
that we worked on this year is something
called blue button blue button in the
healthcare industry has a term that's
been around for a while so I think it
was about in 2010 the Department of
Veterans Affairs started a project
called blue button and the idea was that
this was I think named by someone in
government but the idea was that there
could be one button you could go there
and you could click on it and download
your medical records and this is
something they wanted to launch for
veterans the problem with that is once
you downloaded it you got it in either a
text a text file or a CSV file or an
Excel spreadsheet and it wasn't really
clear to a lot of end-users what they
were going to do with that and how would
be useful to them so the next version we
imagined was it wasn't good enough to
just give people a lot of data but to
give it to them in a way that it would
actually be useful and that's where the
idea for blue button 2.0 came so what
you're looking at is something that we
launched in April this year at a major
health to healthcare technology
conference called hims in Las Vegas and
the blue button 2.0 API is essentially
something that any health technology app
developer can use to integrate into
their product so that Medicare
beneficiaries can see their data in the
context of a health app that they
already use some of the startups that
have used the pin in our Developer
Preview program include organizations
like 23andme 23andme pill pack Siemens
a number of really large organizations
and also a couple of small startups
so essentially what we wanted to do was
make sure that instead of having a bunch
of data locked up in PDFs it could be
given and delivered to someone in the
context of them getting the right data
at the right time to make a better
decision for their own health and we I
think when we launched we had about a
hundred organizations that were signed
up for a sandbox developer account and
we've grown that number over the past
few weeks after we launched it
officially to about 300 and I actually
had a call with some co-workers today I
think it is over 300 now so I should
probably update my slides so I told you
a little bit about some of the projects
that we work on specifically at USGS on
the healthcare team but if you're
interested in sort of getting involved
in sort if you work in an environment
where you're one of a few people who
understand technology in your
organization and you really want to
encourage other people in your
organization to adopt better or modern
arm software development practices you
might find some of the resources that we
put together helpful
there's our digital services playbook
which is playbook CIO gov and then one
thing that we learned pretty early on
interacting with government is that a
lot of times the government agency is
not able to have full-time engineering
staff and so they'll spin out they'll
put out a contract and hire a
contracting firm or a vendor to help
augment their staff and capabilities but
maybe they're not always in the best
position to evaluate how to hire the
best contractor so we put together a
resource where we think of it as agile
procurement so instead of putting out
you know a proposal for millions of
dollars and then hiring someone who may
or may not actually be able to build
something to give the proposal up give
the contract to thinking about a way to
do procurement a little bit more like
the way that we do human Center design
and agile development more iteratively
this is a resource that you can use if
you're in an organization that's quite
and has to procure digital services
often and then if you're interested in
learning more about other projects that
we work on for example at the VA we work
with we have two main programs one is
vet sock of where we are able to help
redesign one central place for veterans
to get access to all their benefits and
then another is a benefits appeals
program where we're trying to simplify a
way for people who are just honorably
unfairly dishonorably just discharged to
appeal to get benefits we're also we
also have programs with DHS to help
people who are applying for asylum
making that process easier for them and
then with SBA helping small businesses
have a fair shot at getting chances to
win some of those contracts so if you're
interested in learning more we're always
hiring you can go to USGS gov /join to
